description: From French inaugural, from inaugurer, from Latin augurare (“to take omens”).

entries.meaning: Of inauguration; as in a speech or lecture by the person being inaugurated.
examples: The University of Cape Town hosts an inaugural lecture by Professor Ian Scott  […]  on Wednesday at 8pm.

entries.meaning: Marking the beginning of an operation, venture, etc.
examples: 2009 was the inaugural season for New York Yankees' new stadium.
The inaugural of the President will take place in March.

entries.meaning: A formal speech given at the beginning of an office.
examples: In his inaugural, President Obama proclaimed 'an end to the petty grievances and false promises, the recriminations and worn-out dogmas, that for far too long have strangled our politics'.
